_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CraftMark Bakery LLC produces cookies, bread, and flatbread at our facility located in Indianapolis, IN. We have a strong commitment to operate our facility in a safe and responsible manner. 

Our facility stores and uses Anhydrous Ammonia as the cooling medium in our refrigeration system. The ammonia is used to cool spaces and product throughout the facility.  In particular the evaporators using ammonia refrigerant cool several process areas, a large storage freezer, and several spiral freezers.  Ammonia is the only substance covered by the Accidental Release Prevention Regulations handled at this facility.  Although ammonia has the potential of being life threatening, our highest priority at CraftMark Bakery is to operate and monitor our facility appropriately so that the refrigeration system will pose little/no threat to the surrounding community.  

At CraftMark Bakery the ammonia is contained in a closed loop system; it is designed to remain inside the piping and vessels in our facility. The pipes and vessels were designed and tested to hold pressure far exceeding the operating pressure produced at the facility. We believe that ammonia provides the safest and most efficient cooling choice for our operation. 

Ammonia is produced in the human body and is commonly found in nature. In nature, ammonia occurs in soil from bacterial processes. It is also produced when plants, animals and animal wastes decay.  Ammonia used as a refrigerant is more concentrated than what is described above.  The word 'anhydrous' means without water.  Anhydrous Ammonia exists as a colorless highly irritating gas with a sharp odor. Ammonia gas is lighter than air and will rise, so that generally it does not settle in low-lying areas. However, in the presence of moisture, ammonia can form vapors that are heavier than air causing it to fall near the ground.  When ammonia enters the body as a result of breathing or skin contact, it can displace the oxygen in your lungs causing suffo

cation.  It also reacts with water to produce ammonium hydroxide, which will cause a burning feeling in a person's eyes, skin, or throat.  Luckily there are warning signs; the odor is so pungent that even people, who have never been in contact with it in the past, will understand that they need to remove themselves from the area. Ammonia is not highly flammable, but containers of ammonia may become unstable exposed to high heat. As said above, the fluid is entirely and continually contained within the circuit for normal operation. The materials of containment are selected to eliminate corrosive or dissociative interactions with the refrigerant. The means of installation and assembly are applied and managed to ensure the highest levels of integrity and operational durability while providing safe and effective access for maintenance. Refrigeration system operators need detail training in the methods to make such accesses and the specific intent of a procedure before any task is undertaken.

We take many precautions to prevent or minimize accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration system.  These precautions include safety controls (alarms and automatic shutdown devices) that are designed to identify and prevent potentially unsafe conditions like pressure increases that could cause a system failure.  We also have a preventive maintenance program designed to maintain the on-going integrity of the systems, a training program designed to ensure that the systems are operated by qualified personnel, and emergency response procedures that enable trained personnel to respond quickly to system upsets. The plant requirement overall is in fact a multi-tiered system of training, supervisory controls and qualifiers, tools, equipment and administrative safeguards running the spectrum from the most generic and all encompassing to the most specific. They are addressed not only to the End User's employees, but also to every person who may now or ever enter the plant.

The EPA's hazard modeling software was used to model the effect of potential ammonia releases. These studies focus on worst-case and alternative releases of ammonia from common ammonia refrigeration equipment.  Documentation was recorded from these studies and can be available upon request.

monia leak sensors are incorporated throughout the facility. One ammonia detector is located in each room that may be exposed to an ammonia leak. Process area room NH3 detectors are located near the evaporators. Cold Storage NH3 detectors are located within each of the rooftop penthouses. In addition, there are three ammonia detectors in the machine room.  Safety relief valves (are installed on each required pressure containing vessel safety relief valves are designed to protect vessels/piping from reaching their maximum working pressure as defined by the U1A data sheets.  The Compressor Control Panels contain many adjustable safety set points for compressor protection. For each of the safety controls, the compressor will go through a series of actions leading up to the shut down of the compressor. These actions follow the following pattern:
1) Alarm - Alarm horn sounds.
2) Delay - Time between when alarm first sounds and Shutdown of compressor. Should the alarm condition fall back into the desired range during this delay, the alarm horn will stop.
3) Shutdown - The compressor shuts itself down. Cause for the shut down must be viewed at either the compressor GForce Panel or computer interface and rectified before machine is started back up, per SOP procedures.  

As stated before, our goal is to prevent accidental chemical releases and minimize their impact if they do occur.  No ammonia-related accidents have occurred at the facility over the past five years that resulted in significant onsite or offsite consequences. 

The facility has an accident release prevention program that complies with Occupational Safety and Health Act's Process Safety Management Standard and EPA's Risk Management Program Rule. The prevention program consists of the following elements: 

¿	Employee Participation Program
Process Safety Management and Risk Management Programs will not be as effective without the involvement of the employees and/or their representatives.  Employee pa

rticipation is provided by making employees aware of PSM and RM Program information, involving them in the development and ongoing maintenance of various elements, and providing access to PSM and RM Program related information.

¿	Process Safety Information
The process safety information includes information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia, information pertaining to the technology of the ammonia refrigeration system, and information pertaining to the equipment in the ammonia refrigeration system. 

¿	Process Hazard Analysis
The PHA was based on a generic study developed by the International Institute of Ammonia Refrigeration (IIAR) and the International Association of Refrigerated Warehouses (IARW).  The generic study was customized and supplemented with unique site-specific issues to ensure that all hazards of this particular ammonia refrigeration system were thoroughly reviewed.  This was done with a qualified PHA leader in a team format, centered on the What-If/Checklist technique.  In general, PHAs are conducted to identify hazard scenarios associated with various kinds of industrial activities.  When hazard scenarios are identified, existing/proposed designs and operations are assessed to determine if appropriate engineering/administrative controls are in place.  If the current level of protection is determined insufficient, recommendations are made to eliminate and/or mitigate the scenarios.  The specific purpose of this study was to identify hazards associated with an ammonia refrigeration system.  Hazards of interests centered on the release of anhydrous ammonia and the potential consequences to employees and surrounding areas.  This study was commissioned by CraftMark Bakery in an effort to address the PHA requirements in 29 CFR 1910.119, OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulation.

¿	Operating Procedures
The purpose of the operating procedures plan is to develop, implement, and maintain clearly written, detailed procedures, guidelines,

rules, and practices for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system during all operating phases. The operating procedures provide all employees involved in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration system with the written information and precautions necessary to safely perform their tasks in a consistent manner. 

¿	Training Program
The purpose of training personnel is to enable them to safely and efficiently operate and maintain the ammonia refrigeration system and increase employee awareness of potential hazards.

¿	Contractor Safety Program
The purpose of the Contractor Program is to help ensure that contractors, subcontractors, and their employees are fully aware of the potential dangers involved with a process covered by the Process Safety Management (PSM) Standard and the Risk Management Program (RM Program) Rule. This awareness should lead to reduce risks of accidents, and thus improved safety, for contract employees, the company's employees, and people in the surrounding area.

¿	Pre-Startup Safety Review Procedures
The purpose of a pre-startup safety review is to help ensure that adequate safety measures are in place and are operational before ammonia is added to a new facility or to an existing facility, which has been modified.

¿	Mechanical Integrity Program
Mechanical integrity programs are in place to assure the continued integrity of process equipment to minimize the risk of a catastrophic ammonia release. One of the goals of a mechanical integrity program should be to substitute break down maintenance with preventative maintenance where appropriate to the equipment used in the process. 
The mechanical integrity program includes the systematic identification process equipment and instrumentation, the development of written procedures for maintaining equipment, training for maintenance employees, a preventive maintenance program for process equipment, a means of assuring that deficiencies in process equipment

that result in operation outside of acceptable limits are corrected, and a quality assurance program.

¿	Hot Work Permit Procedures
The purpose of this procedure is to ensure that employees, contractors, and surrounding areas are properly protected against fire, explosion and other dangers resulting from hot work (cutting and welding and any other spark producing operation such as brazing, grinding, burning and exposure of energized electrical conductors) performed on the company property.

¿	Management of Change Procedures
The objective of this Management of Change (MOC) procedure is to ensure that changes to the ammonia facility are properly reviewed and recorded and that hazards introduced by the implementation of the change are identified and controlled before the change is implemented. The Management of Change procedures also indicate that the facility's PSM and RM Program will be modified as needed and that affected employees are trained.

¿	Incident Investigation Procedures
The purpose of investigating serious incidents and near misses is to understand what happened (or could have happened) and then to prevent any recurrence of similar incidents, thereby improving the safety of the process. Identifying factors that contributed to or root cause(s) of a release, near miss or injury can help lead to improvements and modifications in equipment, training, operations, and management programs.

¿	Compliance Audit Procedures 
This guideline documents the facility's compliance audit plan as it applies to the Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management (RM) Program.  This guideline establishes a procedure to identify any elements of the PSM and RM Program that do not meet the requirements of the PSM Standard and RM Program Rule and to provide a means of responding to deficiencies found by the auditors.
